comments.commentBody:
Why doesn't anyone ever mention that the Social Security Trust Fund was raided by various Washington officials and never paid back. I believe it is trillions. Why can't be demand that money back. It will be more than needed with two generations coming to retirement (from unemployment) with nothing.

I live on a lot less than what the average male makes now. And why are the elderly never mentioned in these statistics. Don't they count at all? Before Social Security the poverty rate for those over 65 was extremely high and before Medicare the rate was over 55%. So now Obama wants to cut those programs badly and the REpublicans want to do away with them. Do they really like to see thousands of homeless hungry poor on the streets begging? Does it give them some sense of superiority? They must be the most insecure people in history.

To 119, Matt from NYC who wrote he sees more fat people than poor I just want to point out how stupid that remark is. Poor people are fat because our food policies makes highly fattening and salty and sweet foods very cheaply available to those who can't afford fresh organic vegetables. And you can't figure out who is poor by just looking. Wake up and learn the truth is more complicated than your shallow little mind can manage. Yes, you are insensitive and clueless. That made me sick to read and made me realize just how bereft of compassion America is.

While I have zero interest in this Missoni stuff, I do think Target should have a limit on the number of items a person can purchase in one transaction, when it comes to highly-hyped, low quantity merchandise.  And I dearly hope the scalpers lose money, since they take all the fun out of bargain hunting.

I don't think we really need to "ignite a storm of hiring" for this to work. Even a small increase in hiring will create a small increase in demand, possibly creating a domino effect. Wishful thinking? Maybe. But the more fire we can put under this economy the better and helping small businesses is a good start.

This is a great article. I agree that they should trying to pick winners and losers with these tax breaks. I just read another news piece which talks about how every industry including corporate jet owners, hedge fund managers, oil companies etc. are complaining that ending their subsidies will rattle the market. Point is that everybody that there is no tax cut or tax raise that can make everybody happy. Everybody wants a tax break and they are okay with raising taxes on somebody else.
We have been waiting for last 10 years for these tax breaks to work. So far I think they have been not as effective as we would like. I can't even figure out how much money I am saving on my payroll due to payroll tax cut since the amount is so small to have any meaningful impact.

I think we need stimulus in other forms - provide incentive to fix housing market, improve infrastructure, invest in education etc. Try to fix what's broken. Just providing tax cuts every feww months is not helping. Tax cuts don't come for free. Tax cuts is also helping increase our deficits which nobody wants to talk about.

"Once again, I have the sense that not everyone in Washington understands how small businesses work. " Ding Ding Ding. We have a winner!! About the only thing the folks in Washington know how to do is graduate from law school. They all seem to know how to keep the govt working, but no idea on how to keep small business working.

Well when the top 1% of Americans have as much as the lowest 90% is it any real surprise? We're getting so top heavy the bottom is going to fall out soon; I wonder where that will leave our economy then? I'm not a communist or anything- but unless we find some way to redistribute the wealth the capitalist system will break. Capitalism works on the assumption people have purchasing power- but a large majority of people in the US no longer do.

The reality is that the poor do manage to "scrape" by with the little they have- but they're forced to live from check to check paying off essential bills, rent, and buying food and gas. There is no money there to to buy consumer goods or save- and many live in constant credit card debt. I know my own mother- when her husband couldn't find a job for 9 months, managed to get a job (paying 1/10 what he made). Only one of them can work at a time since child care is too expensive. It helps that they own their house so they aren't paying rent or a mortgage, but at the end of the month, even after all cuts, they're sunk under credit card payments from essentials they needed to purchase while neither of them had a job.

It shouldn't be an issue of "Class warfare," its an issue of whats best for the United States. The poor don't want to steal money from the rich, they want the opportunity to work and be paid fairly for their work. The poor don't want charity, they want to be independent, but its impossible to live off "Walmart Wages." The rich should realize that if things continue as they are, they will suffer as well. Rather than let it get to a point of no return, we should agree as Americans to restructure our economic and government system that benefits greater equality between income groups.

Again, I'm not saying communism is the answer, but if corporations aren't willing to change themselves, the last choice is government intervention.

1. $10-$12 minimum wage
2. Increased Taxes on top 10%
3. Penalties to outsourcing

The lower 98% have only two ways of changing this:

Draft a 2012 presidential candidate (Elizabeth Warren and Russ Feingold come to mind) who is untainted by corporate contributions and lobbyists.

Boycotting/striking foreign produced/manufactured/American worker exploited goods and services.

The scale has tipped, and the citizenry no longer has the money to buy its own political candidates. And soon there won't be enough money in the hands of the lower 98% to effect a corporate hurt with boycotts on spending.

The time is NOW for last ditch corrective action. If not now, then I fear much, much more violence than civil disobedience. People are suffering, people are dying, and people, historically, will pass a tipping point and revolt.

why is everyone so surprised / upset / appalled?

This is simply the result of the politicians that "WE THE PEOPLE" elected.
George W. Bush just keeps on giving.

Jonathon Swift's "A Modest Proposal" has never been more relevant and less ironic. And yet. while Warren Buffett lamented his own guilty allegorical pleasure in young Irish children - "Oh, we must STOP this, but please pass another young joint around until my peers stop..."

Jim Hightower,Texas, insightfully noted that every manufacturer of washing machines always put the "agitator" in the MIDDLE, not at the side (Warren). However, Warren's input was still welcome and timely given the lock the Republican party had on the tax increase position.

Warren for President !

10 years ago was when ANNUAL double digit increases in health insurance premiums started. Then 9/11 was followed by the 2002 recession and a large number of layoffs. Employers that used to pay some employee premiums gradually stopped, effectively canceling any raises or increased earnings. Then massive layoffs again in 2008, with most of those same people still looking for jobs 3 YEARS LATER.

Forget the six months unemployed metric that gets tossed around and consider that your typical suburban neighborhood street is peppered with families stricken by job loss, underwater mortgages and no relief in sight. The amount of willful ignorance and arrogance toward those suffering is obscene and will have a reckoning for those that think are not yet affected.

This is a triumph of free market capitalism.  The rich are claiming all the benefits and the poor get to carry the load.  The rest of the world looks at Americans and thinks we're naive.  In a rush of good old American optimism we believed we could have it all.  Looks like the rest of the world was right. So will Americans ever wake up and face reality?  Oh, maybe someday.
The "GOP Elite", have proven over time that they cannot stand prosperity and will do anything to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.  They somehow cannot stand to side with the general public.

Interesting to note that Mr. Pawlenty has pledged his wholehearted support for Mr. Romney.....after Romney's top supporters have promised to help him pay off his debt. Is there any part of our political process that doesn't involve money?

"My children are not vaccinated, my family and I do not see doctors"

Awesome. Instead you rely on the fact that other people get vaccinated to keep the incidence of disease low in the population, pretty much the ultimate selfishness. If everybody thought like you we'd still be stuck in the Middle Ages.

"In the years 1964-65, the United States had an estimated 12.5 million rubella cases. This led to 11,000 miscarriages or therapeutic abortions and 20,000 cases of congenital rubella syndrome. Of these, 2,100 died as neonates, 12,000 were deaf, 3,580 were blind and 1,800 were mentally retarded. In New York alone, CRS affected 1% of all births"

Vaccination saves lives!

Side note: I can't believe we are getting to the point where we have to count on Michelle Bachmann and Sarah Palin to criticize "crony capitalism" in politics. I'm not sure either of them really knows what that term means, but that should be enough to get Democrats wilting, as they must realized it's been a LOOOOONG time since any of them had much relevant to say about it.

I live across the street from a hugh high school in an upper middle class area. From what I have seen and found in my yard and in the school's yard and parking lots, teenagers need this vaccine. Notes written to each other leave no doubt they have having sex and the condoms found in the school's parking lots after a prom also tells one what is going on with these teenagers. Cervical cancer is very deadly and difficult to detect. Years ago I applied for a job where a young lady in her 20's was leaving the position because she had cervical cancer. What a tragedy for someone that young.

Years ago sex was not as casual in teens as it is today. This too is a tragedy ...

Ugh.  "Prevents cancer"  "Prevents cancer"-- so many people here are just repeating the factoid they've been told.  I asked my pediatrician, an extremely independent intellectual who is also a professor at a major university hospital, and who teaches a course on ethics and dealing with pharmaceutical representatives' sales tactics--I asked him whether he recommended the HPV vaccination for my daugher, and he shook his head no before I finished the question.  For God's sake people, how do you know it 'prevents cancer, prevents cancer'?  It's barely been out for a few years.  It takes years and years of observation to be able to confirm that a vaccine has reduced incidences of cancer over time.  What kills me is when so many people who unquestioningly accept the pharmaceutical companies' party line (prevents cancer prevents cancer) suddenly have a much, much higher standard for proof of any claim that vaccines might cause some people harm.  You can't have it both ways.  As my pediatrician wisely said, "There are vaccines which  do great things.  There are others that are not so necessary, but profitable.  And there are people who do have terrible, long-term reactions to vaccines.  The problem is that the debate is so polarized, and the denial of any harm is so absolute, that we'll never be able to get research dollars into identifying which children are the ones more likely to have bad reactions.  The way we find out now is to inject them and see if they have a terrible reaction."
There's something really bizarre about a universe in which Rush Limbaugh(of all people!) is the voice of reason.
When was the last time you heard a "politician" admit, "I was wrong, I made a mistake" and own up to it?

“I am not a doctor, I am not a scientist, I’m not a physician”...

Nor is she an intelligent, thinking or ethical individual.

Is there a more idiotic, lame-brained excuse for a human being on the national political stage? (Other than the brain-dead Ohio Republican official who, on NPR today, described Bachmann as "extremely intelligent"?)

A few notes:

A) The only "deaths" reported from this vaccine come from a database that allows anyone to basically submit anything they want.

B) Yes, HPV is a slow growing cancer. However, the cure for the cancer is a hysterectomy. Does anyone here want a hysterectomy they don't need? Yeah I thought so.

C) The vaccine doesn't only protect against cervical cancer. It also helps protect against other kinds of cancers including head and neck cancers. How is that not a worthy goal?

This was the one thing Perry got right. What a pity it's now the one thing he refuses to defend!

Loss of individual freedom to do what, to pass on HPV? Because that's what we old folks from the pre-HPV vaccine did, and still do. The prevalence is roughly 1 in 4. True, most people get it and clear it. But others are not so lucky. Is this what freedom is all about? Playing Healthcare Russian Roulette?

Oh, and FYI, the cancer HPV protects us against is not just cervical--HPV can cause anal and pharyngeal cancers, as well.

But that probably just plays right into the hands of those against this vaccine--if they're squeamish thinking about how missionary sex can pass HPV into a cervix, and would rather see cancers and pre-cancers than prevention, I can't imagine their wanting to prevent cancers associated with oral and anal sex.

Mike - Sadly, you don't get it.  The "Mike" in my life could have explained it to you, but he was murdered on 9/11 (FDNY ladder 132).  So you can keep on living your life just not getting what 9/11 means to many New Yorkers and how it changed us forever.  But please take the "New York City" off your profile.  It IS our national tragedy and YOUR comments are disgraceful.  The Mets helped us gather and mourn the night they came back.  And they gave us a night to help bring some sense of normalcy to people like me and my family.  It ALL meant something.  The tears, Piazza's homerun, more tears, and yes, the hats.  Mark

As a new yorker, I believe the mets and yankees should be allowed to wear either fdny,nypd or emt caps during a 9/11 game. the owners are rich enough to pay the fine on the players behalf.  if not, most players on both teams can afford to eat the fine.   If not, let the players union fight it out with MLB.
